question_text: Why does DDR memory achieve higher effective data rates than single data rate (SDR) memory at the same clock frequency?
answer_options: DDR uses wider data buses with more pins
DDR transfers data on both rising and falling clock edges
DDR operates at double the voltage of SDR memory
DDR modules contain twice as many memory chips
correct_answer: DDR transfers data on both rising and falling clock edges
explanation: DDR (Double Data Rate) transfers data twice per clock cycle - once on the rising edge and once on the falling edge - effectively doubling throughput compared to SDR.
